blog.name: devilsbastion
blog.title: I came from the sea
blog.description:
'Game of Thrones & a Parting Glass' lives here, don't ask why, but you can search by character or author if you wish. and sometimes i snap photos, write words, and paint pictures. and sometimes i realize it's all futile. <!-- Start of StatCounter Code for Tumblr -->
 
 
<!-- End of StatCounter Code for Tumblr -->

blog.name: apiratecalledav
blog.title: You have a good heart. It’s super annoying.
blog.description: Hullo! I'm Av.  You're cool for looking at my blog. I'm not too active these days but it's pretty much all Harry Potter/Fantastic Beasts with a lot of The Dragon Prince, Game of Thrones, The Lord of the Rings, Downton Abbey, The Hunger Games, Girl Meets World, Avatar: The Last Airbender, The Legend of Korra and pretty much whatever else I feel like talking about.

summary: Do you think Gendry will end up Lord of Storm’s End?
question: Do you think Gendry will end up Lord of Storm’s End?
answer:
Assuming you’re asking about the tv show version, it’s certainly possible. Davos witnessed Stannis claiming Gendry as Robert’s, so that might be decent enough proof. It’s at least more concrete than “Hey, that boy sure looks freakishly like Renly.” And if being Lord of Storm’s End is Edric Storm’s endgame in the novels, that makes the chances even more likely. 

However, I don’t think Storm’s End has been mentioned for years and we don’t even know who has it now. I wouldn’t be surprised if it was eaten by the black hole that took Quaithe/ other Qarth stuff, Marya Seaworth, Robert and Cersei’s baby boy, etc. 

At the very least, I think he’ll be allowed to call himself “Gendry Baratheon” and save the name. With Robert killing Rhaegar and trying really hard to end the Targaryen line, it’d be nice to have Rhaegar’s biological son help Robert’s son restore House Baratheon.

But I’m guessing you asked me this in the hopes of Arya/Gendry stuff sooo…

I’m not gonna lie, until the credits roll on the finale, I’m going to hope that they’ll go full “My Feather Bed” and Gendry will be offered it but turn it down…. And at least imply it’s because Arya would prefer him as her “forest love” and being his “forest lass” rather than be lord and lady. Yeah, it’s fairytale-ish and fan fic-y but dammit, I’m prepared for pretty much everyone else having to “settle” and I want Arya to have the happiest ending she can manage.  

It’s actually not completely baseless:

In agot, Ned tells Arya she will marry a king someday and Arya tells him, “No, that’s Sansa.” This, of course, was written when Arya and Jon were most likely meant to end up together so that was probably foreshadowing/irony. She doesn’t necessarily reject the idea of marrying a king; it might just be that she disliked being forced onto the same path as Sansa.  

In the show, when Ned tells Arya that “you will marry a high lord and rule his castle and your sons [will essentially have way more fun than you ever will],”  she says, “No, that’s not me.” True, this might just mean Arya would never be a traditional “proper little lady.” She didn’t seem opposed to being “lord of a holdfast.”  Gendry would obviously value her as an equal and with her brains, compassion, and determination, plus the fact that she’s charming and likable, she is well suited to pretty much anything. But just because she can do something— and do it well—doesn’t mean she’d truly be happy about it. I’m great with little kids but I sure as hell don’t want to run a daycare center.

And ever since Arya talked about seeing the edge of the world with such awe, I feel like all signs point to her “being free” when this is over. Nymeria choosing to stay with her new pack rather than go back to Winterfell seems especially significant, especially when followed up with Arya saying, “That’s not you.” 

Sansa’s great childhood wish was to be a queen/great lady, and for years, only got cruel, twisted versions with Joffrey, Ramsay, Cersei and Littlefinger. Similarly, Arya would have loved to grow up traveling and meeting new people and learning combat techniques but she didn’t get to actually enjoy any of it. She was always on the run from someone trying to kill her and most of the time didn’t even know if she’d be able to get food and water or shelter. 

Just as Sansa has been making her dreams come true on her own terms, Arya deserves the same. I want her to have the chance to experience adventure without having to be afraid or hide who she is. I want her to be able to sit down and befriend random people she comes across and listen to their stories and share her own. I want her to be able to stop by to see her friends and family members without discovering that they’ve just been murdered or recently traumatized.

And Gendry is still the best choice to accompany Arya. Nymeria didn’t leave to become a lone wolf and neither would Arya. She is very sociable and generally likes being around other people, especially the members of her pack.

Plus there’s this conversation between Gendry and Davos:

Davos: I didn’t want to be a lord. I nearly didn’t accept.

Gendry: Why did you?

Davos: I did it for my son. […] I wanted him to have a better life.

Gendry: Does he?

Davos: He’s dead.

Davos and Gendry have a lot in common: They grew up in Flea Bottom, spent half their lives running from the law, and made unlikely friendships with high borns. One of the recurring themes of this series is the new generation making different/better choices than those before them. I could see Davos urging Gendry just to do what makes him happy or Gendry realizing that becoming a lord for Arya’s benefit would ultimately backfire.

Lyanna chose to pursue freedom from everyone’s expectations and a future with Robert by marrying Rhaegar and becoming a princess. Which started a war and got themselves and a whole lot of other people killed.

So perhaps Arya and Gendry will find freedom in a much less destructive way… by leaving titles behind?

 Arya and Gendry could have a nice enough life with crowns of precious metal and a castle but they’d probably be happier with crowns made of golden leaves and a cottage in the forest and I can’t help but hope that’s exactly what they get.

blog.name: thefandomsurvives
blog.description: The Blacklist, Lizzington, Game of Thrones, Jonsa, Sansa Stark, Sherlock, Molly Hooper, Harry Potter, Hermione Granger, + whatever may catch my eye

summary:
Sansa: I saw you with Gendry
Arya: 
Sansa: He was making starry eyes and calling you "m'lady"
Arya: 
Sansa: Then you punched his...
body:
Sansa: I saw you with Gendry
Arya: 
Sansa: He was making starry eyes and calling you "m'lady"
Arya: 
Sansa: Then you punched his arm and threatened to kill him
Arya: 
Sansa: So I want to know... when are you two getting married?
Arya: 
Sansa:  
Arya: New face, who dis?

dialogue.name: Sansa
dialogue.label: Sansa:
dialogue.phrase: He was making starry eyes and calling you "m'lady"

dialogue.label: Sansa:
dialogue.phrase: Then you punched his arm and threatened to kill him

dialogue.label: Sansa:
dialogue.phrase: So I want to know... when are you two getting married?

tags: a song of ice and fire
summary: AU where the Brotherhood makes it to Riverrun with Arya, and Gendry stays with her and joins her brother’s fight. Catelyn has...
body:
where you go, i go

AU where the Brotherhood makes it to Riverrun with Arya, and Gendry stays with her and joins her brother’s fight. Catelyn has tried (and mostly failed) to transform Arya into a princess, but she’s still been spending most of her time with Gendry. This would be just prior to a battle with the Lannisters in which Gendry is supposed to join, but Arya is not.

Gendry swallowed dryly as he watched Arya approach; his mind raced, trying to find the right words. But what was there to say other than he didn’t know how he could physically walk out of this castle thinking he might never see her again? And with her lady mother and brother of a king present, he very well couldn’t say it all like that.

She looked lovely, the icy blue of her gown standing in stark contrast to her storm gray eyes. He could never tell her that either.

When she reached him, her mouth was drawn tightly as she surveyed him for the first time in full armor. Not his own, but armor all the same. Her eyes, however, held a jest.


“Well,” Arya said lightly, “do take care.” Then she reached out a hand and patted his upper arm. Thinking she meant to hug him, he reached out his arms, but she turned swiftly to hug her brother and kiss him on the cheek before sweeping back the way she’d come.


Even Catelyn looked after her in shock. Despite their best efforts to keep Arya in her chambers and away from the forge all those past months, all present had expected a much warmer farewell from the northern princess for the blacksmith she was overly too fond of.


Stupidly, Gendry finally lowered his arms. His elbow still burned from where she’d touched it. His faced burned now too, and surrounded by virtual strangers as he was, he couldn’t express the way he truly felt about her shortness.


Instead, after waiting for Robb to kiss Catelyn’s hand, he fell into step with Robb, who waited until they were out of his mother’s hearing to murmur, “I’m sure she’s just upset she can’t be there.” Robb’s attempt at making him feel better for the slight. But she hadn’t looked upset in the least, and they both knew it. Though Gendry knew Arya had fought her king tooth and nail to be allowed to join them.


Gendry knew now they had made a mistake coming here, though it was useless to think about because Arya never would have been swayed from it. But out there, even in the middle of the war, no matter what they had been facing, they had always been together. The fear Gendry felt in his chest was not from the battle; he couldn’t even think on it. It was the fear of never seeing Arya again, whatever that meant.


The only thought he had to truly console him was that if the battle did take a turn for the worst, Arya would be warm and safe in her bed. This gave Gendry the resolve to stride faster towards war, to mount his horse and ride.


Later, they’d made camp not far from the Lannisters and would wait until dawn to mount an attack. Distracted by his thoughts of Arya, he made a half-assed attempt at a fire that wouldn’t take.


He was distracted now by the thought of what he would say to Arya if he ever did see her again. So distracted he began practicing the conversation out loud.“M’lady,” he started, his hand extended. He dropped his hand and shook his head. “Stupid.”


Then- “Arya…” Here, he stopped again, her name in his mouth feeling forbidden but somehow right at the same time.


“Arry,” he tried, but it only made him sad, flooding his mind with memories of their time with Yoren, at Harrenhall and with the Brotherhood.


His shoulders sagged and he gave up the impromptu rehearsal. “I just thought you cared.” He finished to himself dejectedly.


A rustle of leaves to his left shocked him from his stupor, and he scrambled to pick up his hammer and swiftly turn. He managed to stop the hammer within an inch of Arya’s sword. But she was smiling wildly. “Cared about what?”


Gendry’s breath caught at the sight of her. Not only was she there but she was dressed like a boy again. Gendry hadn’t seen her dressed like this for many moons. It had been all dresses and slippers and fancy braids. Her hair, which had grown shoulder length, was tied behind her head and hidden under a helm. On top of all of it though, it was getting harder and harder to disguise that she was really a woman, no matter how ugly the breeches, no matter how big the boots.

Of course this had been her plan all along. How had he not seen it?


And was this why she had been so flippant?


“Cat got your tongue?” She asked playfully, letting her sword rest against his still lifted hammer with a clang.


Gendry let the hammer lower, grinding it noisily against the metal of her sword. “Stupid.” He said, finally managing to tear his gaze away from her.


She glanced at him questioningly as she sheathed Needle. “Why are you stupid?” The irresistible grin was back.

“You actually expect anyone to believe you’re a boy?” Gendry finally settled for stubbornly.


Arya ignored that. “You mean stupid for thinking I would let you leave without saying goodbye?”


As she spoke she sat at the hastily made fire and worked on it until it was blazing. He was glad now he’d chosen a spot so isolated from the rest of the soldiers.He was surprised she’d noticed he’d even been upset, as careless as she’d seemed back at the castle.

He hadn’t moved from his spot and suddenly he felt her small warm hand slip into his and pull him down next to her in front of the fire. He let her.“Or do you mean stupid for not realizing you’d be seeing me again before the sun had set?”

She struggled to take the hammer from his grasp and place it on the ground.


Then she handed him the wineskin she’d had at her belt. As he drank, she spoke again. “I suppose you are stupid after all.”


He glanced at her, but she was smiling. But it was different than before. As if there was more she wanted to say but couldn’t.Despite the wine, he swallowed, his mouth feeling dry. “I’ll have to tell his Grace, your brother.” He finally managed.


Arya ignored this too. “You said my name before.” And finally Gendry reddened. He hadn’t called her by her name since they’d still been with the Brotherhood.“Say it again.” Her tone was demanding but soft. Almost pleading.


Gendry studied her carefully. The combination of the fire light and light of the dying sun played across her features. And he knew he truly was stupid, like she always said. He should have kept far, far away. It had been complete folly for him to leave the Brotherhood.


If he thought it had been dangerous to spend time around her as a child, as charming as she had already been then, being near her as she grew into womanhood would be lethal.


And because he knew he could deny her nothing that wouldn’t hurt her, his lips parted and he said her name aloud. “Arya.” It was reverential. It was mercy. Breathing the name out was a relief. He knew now without a doubt that he loved her. It wasn’t just companionship and friendship he craved from her but eternity too.

Her gaze rested on his lips. “Stupid.” She said again, seemingly out of breath.“Stupid to think I’d ever let you fight without me. Stupid to think you would.”And then he realized Arya wasn’t here for the fight. She was here for him. She hadn’t decided to come until it had been a certainty he was going.

His own breath grew short. “I thought-.”


“Stupid,” she breathed, interrupting him all the while leaning closer and closer to him.


In the end, it was Gendry resolve’s that crumbled first. He swooped down to meet her lips with his own. And it was at that moment that he realized that he’d been dreaming about doing this for a long time now. She must have too because she seemed to know exactly what to do.

She pulled away for breath first but kept her cheek against his so that their breaths mingled.

“Where you go, I go.” It was a promise. It was hope.

He took her fingers in his and brought them to his lips shakily. “Where you go, I go.” He repeated.

reblog.comment:
where you go, i go

AU where the Brotherhood makes it to Riverrun with Arya, and Gendry stays with her and joins her brother’s fight. Catelyn has tried (and mostly failed) to transform Arya into a princess, but she’s still been spending most of her time with Gendry. This would be just prior to a battle with the Lannisters in which Gendry is supposed to join, but Arya is not.

Gendry swallowed dryly as he watched Arya approach; his mind raced, trying to find the right words. But what was there to say other than he didn’t know how he could physically walk out of this castle thinking he might never see her again? And with her lady mother and brother of a king present, he very well couldn’t say it all like that.

She looked lovely, the icy blue of her gown standing in stark contrast to her storm gray eyes. He could never tell her that either.

When she reached him, her mouth was drawn tightly as she surveyed him for the first time in full armor. Not his own, but armor all the same. Her eyes, however, held a jest.


“Well,” Arya said lightly, “do take care.” Then she reached out a hand and patted his upper arm. Thinking she meant to hug him, he reached out his arms, but she turned swiftly to hug her brother and kiss him on the cheek before sweeping back the way she’d come.


Even Catelyn looked after her in shock. Despite their best efforts to keep Arya in her chambers and away from the forge all those past months, all present had expected a much warmer farewell from the northern princess for the blacksmith she was overly too fond of.


Stupidly, Gendry finally lowered his arms. His elbow still burned from where she’d touched it. His faced burned now too, and surrounded by virtual strangers as he was, he couldn’t express the way he truly felt about her shortness.


Instead, after waiting for Robb to kiss Catelyn’s hand, he fell into step with Robb, who waited until they were out of his mother’s hearing to murmur, “I’m sure she’s just upset she can’t be there.” Robb’s attempt at making him feel better for the slight. But she hadn’t looked upset in the least, and they both knew it. Though Gendry knew Arya had fought her king tooth and nail to be allowed to join them.


Gendry knew now they had made a mistake coming here, though it was useless to think about because Arya never would have been swayed from it. But out there, even in the middle of the war, no matter what they had been facing, they had always been together. The fear Gendry felt in his chest was not from the battle; he couldn’t even think on it. It was the fear of never seeing Arya again, whatever that meant.


The only thought he had to truly console him was that if the battle did take a turn for the worst, Arya would be warm and safe in her bed. This gave Gendry the resolve to stride faster towards war, to mount his horse and ride.


Later, they’d made camp not far from the Lannisters and would wait until dawn to mount an attack. Distracted by his thoughts of Arya, he made a half-assed attempt at a fire that wouldn’t take.


He was distracted now by the thought of what he would say to Arya if he ever did see her again. So distracted he began practicing the conversation out loud.“M’lady,” he started, his hand extended. He dropped his hand and shook his head. “Stupid.”


Then- “Arya…” Here, he stopped again, her name in his mouth feeling forbidden but somehow right at the same time.


“Arry,” he tried, but it only made him sad, flooding his mind with memories of their time with Yoren, at Harrenhall and with the Brotherhood.


His shoulders sagged and he gave up the impromptu rehearsal. “I just thought you cared.” He finished to himself dejectedly.


A rustle of leaves to his left shocked him from his stupor, and he scrambled to pick up his hammer and swiftly turn. He managed to stop the hammer within an inch of Arya’s sword. But she was smiling wildly. “Cared about what?”


Gendry’s breath caught at the sight of her. Not only was she there but she was dressed like a boy again. Gendry hadn’t seen her dressed like this for many moons. It had been all dresses and slippers and fancy braids. Her hair, which had grown shoulder length, was tied behind her head and hidden under a helm. On top of all of it though, it was getting harder and harder to disguise that she was really a woman, no matter how ugly the breeches, no matter how big the boots.

Of course this had been her plan all along. How had he not seen it?


And was this why she had been so flippant?


“Cat got your tongue?” She asked playfully, letting her sword rest against his still lifted hammer with a clang.


Gendry let the hammer lower, grinding it noisily against the metal of her sword. “Stupid.” He said, finally managing to tear his gaze away from her.


She glanced at him questioningly as she sheathed Needle. “Why are you stupid?” The irresistible grin was back.

“You actually expect anyone to believe you’re a boy?” Gendry finally settled for stubbornly.


Arya ignored that. “You mean stupid for thinking I would let you leave without saying goodbye?”


As she spoke she sat at the hastily made fire and worked on it until it was blazing. He was glad now he’d chosen a spot so isolated from the rest of the soldiers.He was surprised she’d noticed he’d even been upset, as careless as she’d seemed back at the castle.

He hadn’t moved from his spot and suddenly he felt her small warm hand slip into his and pull him down next to her in front of the fire. He let her.“Or do you mean stupid for not realizing you’d be seeing me again before the sun had set?”

She struggled to take the hammer from his grasp and place it on the ground.


Then she handed him the wineskin she’d had at her belt. As he drank, she spoke again. “I suppose you are stupid after all.”


He glanced at her, but she was smiling. But it was different than before. As if there was more she wanted to say but couldn’t.Despite the wine, he swallowed, his mouth feeling dry. “I’ll have to tell his Grace, your brother.” He finally managed.


Arya ignored this too. “You said my name before.” And finally Gendry reddened. He hadn’t called her by her name since they’d still been with the Brotherhood.“Say it again.” Her tone was demanding but soft. Almost pleading.


Gendry studied her carefully. The combination of the fire light and light of the dying sun played across her features. And he knew he truly was stupid, like she always said. He should have kept far, far away. It had been complete folly for him to leave the Brotherhood.


If he thought it had been dangerous to spend time around her as a child, as charming as she had already been then, being near her as she grew into womanhood would be lethal.


And because he knew he could deny her nothing that wouldn’t hurt her, his lips parted and he said her name aloud. “Arya.” It was reverential. It was mercy. Breathing the name out was a relief. He knew now without a doubt that he loved her. It wasn’t just companionship and friendship he craved from her but eternity too.

Her gaze rested on his lips. “Stupid.” She said again, seemingly out of breath.“Stupid to think I’d ever let you fight without me. Stupid to think you would.”And then he realized Arya wasn’t here for the fight. She was here for him. She hadn’t decided to come until it had been a certainty he was going.

His own breath grew short. “I thought-.”


“Stupid,” she breathed, interrupting him all the while leaning closer and closer to him.


In the end, it was Gendry resolve’s that crumbled first. He swooped down to meet her lips with his own. And it was at that moment that he realized that he’d been dreaming about doing this for a long time now. She must have too because she seemed to know exactly what to do.

She pulled away for breath first but kept her cheek against his so that their breaths mingled.

“Where you go, I go.” It was a promise. It was hope.

He took her fingers in his and brought them to his lips shakily. “Where you go, I go.” He repeated.

trail.content_raw:
where you go, i go

summary:
Jaqen H'ghar: A girl gives a man his own name?
Arya Stark: That's right. A man can go kill himself.
Jaqen H'ghar: Stop being so...
body:
Jaqen H'ghar: A girl gives a man his own name?
Arya Stark: That's right. A man can go kill himself.
Jaqen H'ghar: Stop being so mean to me or by the gods I'm gonna fall in love with you!
